Explain why a nucleus has zero dipole moment. what information does the measurement of the electric quadrupole moment of nucleus provides?

  1. A dipole moment is created when a separation exists between positive and negative charges in a system.

    The formula for dipole moment, where Q is the charge magnitude and the r is the charge separation distance: μ = Q × r

  2. A stable nucleus does not have a separation of charges. Instead their distributions of mass and charge are spherically symmetric.

  3. This means that the centre of mass and charge of coincide at the center of the atom. This results in there being zero dipole moment.

  4. A deformation of the electric quadrupole moment of an atom shows us how much its nuclear charge distribution deviates from a perfect sphere.

  5. A positive EQM indicates an elongation of the charge distribution along its axis of spin. A negative EQM indicates a flattening of the charge distribution along the axis of spin.

  6. The character of the EQM can be used to test nuclear models. The shell model predicts that nuclei with a “magic numbers” of nucleons should be spherically symmetric and so should have near-zero quadrupole moments.

  7. The quadrupole hyperfine structure occurs due to the the nuclear EQM interacting with the electric field gradient created by the surrounding electrons in atoms, ions and molecules.
